11:09 am
PM

Quick bit of Renaissance Capital

PM

From the frontiers of investment

PM

The most important news for Frontier investors is that opposition candidate Mauricio Macri scraped a victory in the Argentina presidential elections with 51.5% of the vote. He will be sworn in on 10th December. Argentina has been an underweight for most Frontier funds – according to Dan Salter’s work. Most funds have been overweight industrialising Asia (Vietnam, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Sri Lanka) as well as Saudi Arabia (an off-index overweight in preference to un-transparent Kuwait).

11:09 am
PM

Since we compiled the figure above at the end of September, the Argentina market has rallied over 40%, perhaps partly at the expense of the Saudi overweights (Saudi is down around 5% over the same period). Argentina is MSCI Frontier’s third largest market with a 10% weighting. A number of frontier funds are now telling us that stocks look expensive.

PM

A policy priority for Macri is expected to be a currency devaluation. Our REER analysis purports to show that the ARS is a deeply undervalued currency (with a fair value of ARS5/$), but we have repeatedly noted that this is because Argentina under the Kirchners have produced inflation figures that no-one believes since at least 2007. One client who was in Argentina last month told us Argentina was as expensive as the US, and that ARS20/$ would be more realistic than the official ARS9.7/$ rate. The offshore ARS rate cited by Bloomberg on 18th November suggested ARS14.9/$. NDFs 12-months out suggest ARS17-18/$. Locals may have been trying to protect themselves from this by buying equities.

PM

Interesting dynamic -- investors protecting themselves against a conservative who might even fix the Argentine economy

Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 344.00, down 14.5 (-4.04%), High: 367.00, Low: 280.00, Volume: 3.21m
PM

Sheesh

BE

Which is ........ curious, given its very compressed shareholder base.

11:17 am
BE

To remind, Odey has a 19.5% stake here.

BE

Bought at an average, I make it, of 393p.

BE

We're also heading into the year end. Though you can create your own conspiracy theory out of those facts.

11:18 am
BE

What we can do is remind what holding Plus500 means. It's been so long since we viewed it as a normal company, it's worth a refresher.

BE

So Plus last year did 100% trading revenue growth at a 64% Ebitda margin

BE

And City Index, the UK's oldest CFD provider, has posted declining revenue for the past few years on an Ebitda margin of 9%.

11:19 am
BE

That's because they're not in the same market at all.

BE

Plus500 has nothing to do with financial markets, except by accident really.

BE

It's an online casino. It's a casino that uses contracts rather than roulette.

11:20 am
BE

As per the admission docs, page 18 ....

BE

http://www.plus500...issionDocument.pdf

BE

Profit or loss on customer trading positions
The Group also earns revenue from gains (offset by losses) on customers’ trading positions. When a customer places an order to purchase or sell a CFD, the Group actually sells or purchases the CFD with that customer, even if it does not have a seller or buyer against whom to match that trade. In doing so, the Group acts as principal and takes the risk inherent in the trading position, with the opportunity of gain or loss against the customer only. Net gains/losses to the Group from trading positions represent actual losses/gains made by the Group’s customers.

11:20 am
BE

So Plus500 has told us it acts "as principal and take the risk inherent in the trading position, with the opportunity of gain or loss against the customer only"

BE

As in, it's a casino.

BE

It identifies the worst punters and targets them, to take their money as quickly as possible.

11:20 am
BE

It uses exactly the same methods to identify the punters who present too much risk to the house.

BE

The upshot is that Plus500 burns through customers, exactly like a casino.

BE

It spends a third of revenue on marketing just to make sure customer numbers are replenished.

11:21 am
BE

Exactly like a casino.

BE

(Though whereas casinos spend revenue on Siegfried and Roy and Celine Dion...

BE

... Plus500 spends it on affiliate marketing

11:21 am
BE

With a small amount left over for horrifically bad, misogynistic advertising.)

BE
BE

The customer burn rates are of course the reason it needs to bring in new suckers with indecent haste, which was the FCA's gripe.

11:22 am

BE

CFD's are interesting generally. In that they're not manilla contracts. They can say whatever the issuer chooses, which is why they're ideal for online casinos.

BE

You can write yourself a double-zero into the small print.

BE

So no-one on the sellside covers Plus. Liberum and ..... Canaccord, was it? ..... were restricted on the deal.

11:25 am

Sos here's some Playtech sellside instead.

(@roddy1234: the latter. Or the former. Perhaps the allusion to brown envelopes was a Freudian slip.)

BE

Here's Canaccord.

11:26 am
BE

This is clearly disappointing, given the strategic growth opportunities within the Online
Financial Trading sector. And the impact on forecasts is material. We strip out both
Plus500 and AVA Trade from our forecasts, and as a result, our FY15 Ebitda forecast
coming down from €256.5m to €245.1m, reducing EPS from 63.3c to 60.2c. Our FY16F
Ebitda forecast falls from €390.8m to €290.4m, which drives a 24% EPS downgrade
from 90.8c to 68.8c. However, it is important to note that given the absence of these
deals, Playtech will now have estimated FY15F year end net cash of €995m, with scope
for value accretive deals or returns of cash to shareholders. We would expect to get
some clarity on this at the time of the Prelims in February.

BE

Playtech shares have performed strongly this year, up by 24% against the backdrop of a
declining UK market. Following our downgrades, the shares are on a FY16F PER of 17.7x,
but this drops to 13.8x on a cash-adjusted basis, and it is on an EV/Ebitda of 12.1x. We
think this looks attractive given structural growth opportunities. We reduce our TP from
1065p to 1000p to reflect the downgrades, putting the shares on a prospective FY17
PER of 15.0x (ex-cash) and EV/Ebitda of 12.5x. BUY.

BE

And Citi.

11:29 am
BE

Yup, a Sunday Times push-me-pull-you.

BE

It might be a PE target if the valuation stays depressed, but not before Christmas, and if it rallies it won't be any more.

11:30 am
Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 110.20, up 6.8 (+6.58%), High: 111.00, Low: 108.70, Volume: 2.93m
BE

Showing only that I'm an idiot. Still, it's a good Sunday tale, and the figures make some sense.

BE

The other theory going round last week was that Amazon might be interested in Home, which makes rather less sense to me.

11:31 am
BE

Does Amazon want a bunch of lease liabilities? What's it's expertise there?

BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Over-engineered Argos strategy. The root cause of Argos' problems in our
view is that the current management team have run into execution issues
in their attempt to modernize and digitize the Argos operating model.
In particular by moving to a somewhat over-engineered hub and spoke
model, this has led to a build up of operating cost and stock availability
issues.

11:32 am
BE

Examining the strategic options. We think a more effective alternative
strategy for Home Retail would be to manage Argos less for LFL sales
and more for margin and cash. We think it could look to shrink the store
estate down to a more manageable size, focus on smaller convenient pickup
points, try to differentiate the offer more and shift the product mix
to higher margin areas.

BE

Potential value in Home Retail with the right strategy and execution. As
the Sunday Times article suggests, we think there is potential for value
in Home Retail given that it generated c.£200mn of operating cashflow in
FY15 and it has c.£200mn of net cash and a net loan book of c.£550mn,
which together make up most of the market cap of c.£900mn. As such the
core Argos business is effectively being valued at just 1-2x trailing (FY15)
EBIT of £129mn.

PM

Welcome to ML

11:32 am
BE

Home Retail also owns the marginally profitable Homebase business; its
capex of £175mn could be cut to below depreciation of £150mn and it has
a relatively high tax rate of 24% which we think can be managed down
over time.

BE

Investec too ..........

BE

Lowly valuation unsurprisingly attracting opportunistic interest according to weekend press reports with The Sunday Times suggesting private equity firms are considering launching £1bn takeover bids for HOME. The shares have been under pressure recently following a pre-Christmas profit warning and question marks raised over Argos’s Transformation Plan. Although reports appear vague (and any potential bidders will likely wait until after the peak trading update), we believe significant valuation support resides in HOME.
Balance sheet analysis suggests an adjusted EV/EBIT of -0.7x with the business in a net cash position (FY16e £200m) as well as having a fully-funded loan book, which by year-end will be in excess of £600m on our estimates. We detail our adjustments on page 2. A valuation of c.£1bn (market cap) would value the group on 1.1x adjusted EV/EBIT.
Strategic / trading uncertainty surrounds Argos heading into peak with management unusually tempering FY expectations at October’s interims. Such caution we understand was driven by the competitive industry backdrop (and consumer pullback) heading into Black Friday, for which Argos has tried more recently to spread demand through November.
We continue to see HOME as a value play in its own right. Significant strides have been made to restructure Homebase and Argos’s business model is capable of delivering operational leverage through an efficient multi-channel model. However, market sentiment (and external interest) is likely to wait until proof of delivery through peak at Argos for confidence in its plans to build.

11:33 am
BE

Stifel, meanwhile, has previously put around the Amazon-Argos idea ........

BE

.... though it made the mistake of any Home Retail buyer: it actually went into one of the stores.

BE

The headline article in The Sunday Times hints that £1bn bids are being lined
up for Home Retail Group. The only potential bidder featured in the article is
Apollo Global Management but the same paper details that former Kingfisher
and Home Retail Group CEOs are lined up to start working at True Capital.
Remember also that we do see Amazon as a potential bidder for Argos due to
significant overlap in the product offer and operations.

£1bn per se doesn't sound too generous, equating to 123p per share for a
group with around £550m of financial services receivables and a forecast net
cash position of over £200m. However, we believe Home Retail is particularly
vulnerable to a bid, as trading remains weak despite the fact that management
has spent the past three years modernising the group.

11:34 am
BE

Bid vulnerability is exacerbated by clear current trading problems, led by
systems glitches, just one week before Black Friday and five weeks before
Christmas. On Saturday, we went into the High St Kensington "digital" store
and around one-third of the ipads were frozen; those that were working
showed very poor availability in toys and frustrating search functionality. A4
sheet signage detailed that the chain was experiencing a network outage in a
number of stores affecting the following systems: Home Delivery Issues
Queries, Card Payment, Tablet Issues. By Sunday there was no obvious
improvement. Alongside intermittent website failures, one has to suspect that
trading may be weaker than that disclosed in the recent Q2 update (-2.8%
LFL, +125bps gross margin).

BE

So ............. Dunno right now. I guess the PE suggestion puts a floor under Home.

PM

hmm

11:35 am
BE

But it doesn't do anything for Christmas trading, nor for the scary operational gearing in the business.

BE

One category disappoints -- TVs, mobiles, tablets, whatever -- and you have another profit warning on the way.

BE

And remember, Home's already warned before Black Friday.

11:36 am
BE

Here's an old Barclays note to show the operational gearing involved here.

BE

Firstly, HOME’s valuation on 10.7x 1y fwd PE could be supportive as it trades 20% below its long term average and 30% below the sector average. Historically though when earnings momentum has been significantly negative, as it is now, valuation has provided little support given HOME is a very operationally leveraged company with a 1% LFL change causing a c10% EPS change. Secondly, small share price bounces cannot be ruled out in the run up to Christmas on potential headlines that Christmas spending in general may be robust. Management warned on the cost of the investments to support sales growth into peak but sales are uncertain. If the improvements in the infrastructure do work (e.g. same day delivery) then Argos LFLs could indeed grow. Equally though execution will be key, while tablets, video games and unbranded TVs will likely remain challenged and the outcome for toys is uncertain.

BE

The "PE interested in bombed-out company" is a good line though.

11:37 am
BE

Could say the same of, for example, Aggreko.

BE

Around which there have been similar rumours over recent days.

11:43 am
BE

Turns buyer on it, in fact.

BE

n Raising Imperial to Buy – We now believe a takeover is more likely than we did
before FT Alphaville reported on Nov 20th that “advisers to BAT” have put together a
group of banks “willing to support an offer”. Our price target now assumes a 33%
chance of a bid. Even without a bid the underlying investment is decent (playing
well to our strategists’ themes – a high and growing dividend; exposure to Europe;
self help) IMT’s P/E is much lower than other consumer staples: 14.7X CY16E EPS.

PM

(roddy -- i may have, will delete after the session. Apologies all round)

11:44 am
BE

n We lay out the pros and cons — In the past we have argued a bid was unlikely
because of the anti-trust complexities involved. In this report we go through the pros
and cons from BAT’s point of view, and conclude a bid is financially attractive –
although that doesn’t mean we think there is a greater-than-50% chance.

BE

So here are the pros ..............

BE

11:44 am
BE

And here are the cons

BE

BE

And here's the conclusion.

11:45 am
BE

n Possibly mid teens EPS accretion for BAT — Our simple model assumes BAT
buys assets that generate 50% of IMT’s profit, and it gives an EPS accretion of
17%. (This is based on synergies of 25% of sales, a 3% coupon, and staying below
4x ND/EBITA (ex synergies), which implies paying mostly with equity).

n Other arguments in favour — In addition to the direct EPS effects, removing
Imperial will ensure better price discipline in Europe and Australia ahead of plain
packaging; and give BAT greater DM exposure. BAT may get UK tax benefits too.

BE

n Arguments against — The deal would be extremely difficult for anti-trust reasons,
with BAT having to agree a complicated disposal package ahead of time. Buying
Imperial would dilute sales growth (due to both its brands and its geography), and
reduce BAT’s exposure to EMs. Furthermore, there is no particular reason to do the
deal now as we don’t believe that BAT has run out of organic growth.

n Reiterate Buy on BAT — We believe that on an as-is basis BAT is at an inflexion
point in terms of organic EBIT growth, and on top of this a deal (if it happens) could
add mid-teens to EPS.

11:49 am
BE

BE

BE

Coal worth noting too.

11:50 am
BE

Interesting piece out of Deutsche Bank, suggesting coal producers are trying to bail out a leaky boat at the moment.

BE

They can't cut fast enough to offset Indian production.

BE

While a number of producers globally have been shutting capacity in the face
of weakening demand, Indian domestic coal production has been better than
expected. Indian imports of thermal coal have fallen 27% yoy in September as
a result of the better domestic production. Our commodity has consequently
downgraded the thermal coal forecasts with 2016 Newcastle FOB forecast
down -3.8% to US$51/t and 2017 down -5.8% to US$49/t. In the UK miners
under coverage, only the diversifieds have coal exposure. Putting the new
prices through has had a modest negative impact on our earnings estimates
for these companies.

11:51 am
BE

The prospect of better output growth from the Indian domestic coal industry adds to our conviction on sustained thermal coal weakness in the medium term and led us to lower our forecast. In October, Coal India exceeded its output target and is on its way to report highest y-o-y growth of production after listing in 2010. This compounds the negative consequences of rising capacity in China’s high-voltage long-distance power transmission network which will suppress coastal import demand and possibly even contribute to net exports as governmental policy favours domestic producers. We expect export producers to further cut the cost and benefit from low oil prices and strengthening of USD in coming years; however, oversupply is likely to stay as any closures of high-cost operations will be offset by projects in ramp-up.

BE

Of the European stocks under coverage, only Anglo, BHP, Glencore, Rio and South 32 are impacted by the forecast coal price changes. While the spot price changes have been noted above, the changes to the Japanese benchmark prices are more muted (-5.8% in 2016 only). For 2016 earnings expectations, the two largest impacts were Anglo (-7.9%) and Glencore (-6.7%).

BE

To derive our TPs, we generally use DCF valuations of life of mine cash flows. The key risks to are significant differences in commodity prices and exchange rates from our forecasts, M&A valuation and integration, raw material costs, energy costs, geopolitical changes, execution of replacement and growth projects, project budget overruns and funding, fiscal/mining legislation changes and increasing country risk. Permitting, environmental requirements, staffing and equipment availability and community relations are also risks.

Oh, couple of pushes for Ocado this morning. Were working earlier.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 350.60, down 1.2 (-0.34%), High: 370.00, Low: 349.60, Volume: 1.49m
BE

Now, not so much. Here's UBS.

11:59 am
BE

Having looked in depth at most corners of the earth, we think Ocado
is comfortably ahead of anybody else in making online grocery profitable and scalable.
With the market in our view overplaying fears on Amazon Fresh's possible arrival and
expectations cooling on a new partner, we raise our rating to Buy, maintaining our
480p PT.

BE

Amazon Fresh fears have been overplayed we think
Unconfirmed but widely reported speculation that Amazon Fresh will imminently arrive
in the UK looks to have pressured Ocado's shares but we think fears have been
overdone; service standards in the UK online grocery market will be hard to replicate
quickly (picking, packing and delivering 40-50 perishable products presents different
challenges to a non-food order) and it will also take time to build the buying scale
needed to disrupt industry pricing, albeit, Amazon Fresh could in time get there.

Delivery of a partner may be late but we think it is still coming
Ocado said that it expected (but didn't guarantee) to sign a new partner in 2015 but,
with c90% of the year complete, it hasn't happened yet. We think the unique business
model is attractive but, in our view, some expectations in the market had become too
optimistic (it was the reason we cut the shares from Buy to Neutral in July). With some
of the heat coming out as the year has wound on, we see greater scope for surprise.

Valuation: PT unchanged but shares currently driven by events
Our 480p PT is unchanged and values the core Ocado.com business (including the
intellectual property therein) at 1.8x revenue. We then incorporate 3 partnerships; one
already live (Morrisons.com) and two prospective. We value each partnership at £400m
(£20m of EBIT at 20x). Ocado's shares are driven by catalysts / expectations however
rather than 'fair value' and in our view, the market has become too cautious.

12:00 pm
BE

Ocado’s shares have underperformed the STOXX 600 retail Index by 10%
over the last four months, on concerns over the timing of the signing of its
first International deal and fears that Amazon entry into the UK market may
impact Ocado in particular. In our view, the market should be more interested
in the nature and the potential economics (in terms of fee structure and
costs/capex) of hypothetical deals rather than the actual timing of the
announcement. Our belief is that Ocado should be able to sign its first
International deal soon, proving that it can recoup its own capital investment
relatively quickly via an appealing fee structure. Separately, we are of the
view that Amazon will accelerate the structural shift to online, potentially
triggering more deals for Ocado as its development in the UK generates
anxiety at other bricks & mortar players in different markets, willing to have
their own online platform in place before Amazon steps in. Importantly,
Ocado’s core grocery business continues to grow revenues steadily at c15%
(vs the market at c10% and the UK reported grocers at high single digits),
accelerating in volume terms as deflation increases, consistently gaining
market share. We believe that this trend is set to continue as Ocado benefits
from the SKU axe and net space closures we expect to see at the Big 4 in the
near future.

The stumbling block for any would-be bidder is likely to be Home Retail's
rental liabilities (c.£333mn in the year to Feb 15) which means it is not
under-leveraged (cal. 15 lease-adj.net debt/EBITDAR of just over 4x).
However the good news is the Argos store estate is more flexible these
days (average lease length c. 5 years).
